Dear Mr. Johnson:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
October 24, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions.
In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please
contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(e) Three dated references which are obtained
prior to employment from persons unrelated to
the employee and which are less than 12
months old.

Two of forty-four new staff did not have three references completed within 12
months prior to hire. The staff had three references completed but they were
completed in 2019 and/or 2020 and there were no updated references found in
the employee file.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• If youth are at the facility over 30 days, they need to have reports completed
every 15 days after the 30-day mark.
• For updated services plans, the facility noted the system they complete their
reports in changes the report completion date every time the file is reopened.
Therefore, the report must be printed on the day it's due or prior to ensure timely
compliance is reflected on printed report for the file.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Make sure the total number of training hours are filled out on the job specific
training sheet in the employee files. This will help ensure Consultants know 16
hours of orientation are completed when the orientation training doesn't register
on the staff member's Relias training record.
• Make sure the staff listing that is provided to the Consultant has the employee's
full legal names as listed on their legal form of identification.
• Ensure job descriptions staff are signing off on match their roles listed on facility's
staff list.

• Multiple staff members reported having in person First Aid/CPR training would be
preferable and helpful as they do not feel comfortable doing CPR based on the
online training they completed.
• It is suggested the facility explore multiple times for staff meetings to occur in
order to allow all staff the opportunity to participate.
• It is suggested shadow shifts include shadowing on all shifts since most of the
intakes of youth into the program happen during 3rd shift. In addition, if staff
members ever fill in for other staff members on 3rd shift, it would be helpful for
them to have the experience to do so.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plan not related to maltreatment
during this licensing period. The facility began hiring staff in June 2023 and began
receiving youth placed into the program as of 8/1/23. As a result, the facility was
able to fully implement their CAP addressing their violation for Rule 400.4104 (2)
Rules Compliance.
Financial Overview
The facility's financial audit and budget were reviewed. There were no concerns
with their financial information.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) noted they began taking placements of youth as of 8/1/23
and believe they've been able to resolve all previous issues that resulted in them
being placed on a provisional license in June 2022. They noted they have moved
forward with training and utilizing their approved non-restraint policy during the
period of review. CA noted most of the non-compliances that led to the provisional
license were due to a lack of staff training. CA reported since re-opening, they
have focused on doing more intensive trainings, so staff feel comfortable in their
knowledge of policies, procedures, and supervision requirements. CA also noted
changing their program statement to narrow the scope of youth they accept into
their program has also helped them be able to provide the best care possible for
those youth accepted. CA noted they have implemented all CAP action steps and
have seen positive impacts to their staff and programming as a result. The facility
did not have any unplanned discharges during the period of review. CA noted all

training for staff will continue to be tracked and documented by training
coordinator, and all HR documents will be reviewed thoroughly to ensure any staff
or volunteers are properly cleared before working with youth.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported they have great leadership. They reported they feel listened to and
heard by management and leadership. They reported if they have any concerns or
feel something needs to change, they are comfortable expressing their thoughts.
They reported they all feel like a family, and everyone checks in with each other
frequently. They reported they feel things are communicated well and if there are
changes to policies or procedures, they receive the information timely. Two staff
members interviewed also worked for the facility before they stopped taking youth
for a period. Those two staff members reported things are much better this time
around. They feel they have more staff to complete the tasks and responsibilities,
things are explained much better, they have more support, and they have better
processes in place.
All the youth interviewed reported they felt safe at the facility, they had plenty of
food, they liked the food provided and the staff treated them well. None of the
youth had any concerns or issues to discuss regarding the facility.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of the facility was conducted on 10/24/23 and there were no
concerns noted. It should be noted there are only youth occupying Building 1 and
Building 2. Currently, the facility is not utilizing Building 3 for youth occupancy.
However, one hallway in Building 3 is set up for youth if needed. The other hallway
in Building 3 is currently being utilized for staff offices.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
